Fig 9 Heteroatom-doped M-N4-C Single-atom catalysts towards electrochemical reactions of CO2: A machine learning-assisted DFT study Yiheng Huang Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization Jiarui Wang Writing – review & editing Formal analysis Hui Hu Writing – review & editing Data curation Zhengping Qiao Writing – review & editing Supervision Formal analysis ⁎ Yan Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ Chengxin Wang Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization State Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Materials and Technologies, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, People's Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Materials and Technologies School of Materials Science and Engineering Sun Yat-sen University People's Republic of China Guangzhou 510275 State Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Materials and Technologies, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The local coordination environment regulation of M-N4-C type single-atom catalysts (SACs) by introducing heteroatom (X = B, C, O, P, S) have attracted significant attention for their controllable properties and fantastic catalytic activity in the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). However, the numerous possible configurations of M-NX-C result in excessive computational costs. Herein, we tackled that issue via machine learning-assisted density functional theory (DFT) calculations outperforming the conventional time-consuming high-throughput screening. Initially, DFT calculations demonstrate that the adsorption energy of CO can serve as a high-efficiency descriptor to predict the CO2RR performance of M-NX-C SACs. Then, using this descriptor we screened quite a few superior SACs toward CO2RR using machine learning model of extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) which can predict the catalytic performance of SACs with various parameters regarding local structures of metal centers. Those screened SACs of PtN3B, RhN4, TiN2P2-ortho, FeN2O2-para (experimentally proven recently), CoN4 (experimentally proven), NiN3B and CuN3B possess quite competitive limiting potentials, which have also been further validated by DFT calculations, exhibiting a faithful predictive ability of the XGBoost model. Besides, effective regulation strategies of local environments for promising CO2RR performance were proposed for the most widely investigated M-N4-C (M = Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) SACs. This work is significant for understanding the mechanism of the nearest neighbor regulation of M-N4-C SACs for CO2RR and guiding the future experimental synthesis of them. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 reduction reaction Single-atom catalyst Heteroatom regulation Density functional theory Machine learning Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the continuous consumption of fossil fuels, the greenhouse effect caused by excessive emission of CO2 has generated various environmental crises and provoked worldwide concern. Thus, converting CO2 into valuable chemicals has extracted extensive research interests to achieve sustainable development [1–3]. Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (CO2RR) is a promising strategy to reduce CO2 into C1 and C2 product (e.g., CO, HCOOH, CH3COOH and C2H4). Carbon monoxide (CO), as the foundation of one carbon chemistry and the reactant to synthesize organic compounds, is a promising reducing product [4–8]. However, the reduction of CO2 requires overcoming a high energy barrier. With multiple products produced by the reduction reactions, the selectivity of product is also an issue. Furthermore, while reducing CO2, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), as a side reaction, also easily occurs [9–11]. Therefore, it is necessary to design and synthesize catalysts with excellent performance and high selectivity of CO2RR. Among the various catalysts discovered [4,12–16], single-atom catalysts (SACs) have gained much attraction due to its special electron structure, full utilization of metal atom and flexible coordination environment [3,10,11,17]. As the most investigated configuration of SACs, single transition metal atom anchored on nitrogen-doped graphene nanomaterials (M-N4-C, M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, etc.), have exhibited potential for reducing CO2 to CO [6,18–23]. However, those M-N4-C SACs still face the challenge of unsatisfactory performance. In this case, regulating the coordination environment is one of the effective strategies to improve their catalytic performance [22,24–31]. Taking M-N4-C as the foundation, introducing heteroatom into the first shell around the metal center modifies the properties of the SACs, producing M-NX-C SACs. These types of catalysts have been studied in several key reactions such as carbon dioxide reduction [32–36], oxygen reduction [37,38], sulfur reduction/evolution [39–44], and so on. However, few studies have systematically investigated the impact of coordination tuning on the catalytic performance of M-N4-C toward CO2RR. As far as we know, only one previous work investigated the trapping capabilities of small part of M-NX-C SACs for CO instead of their CO2RR performances [45]. In this work, we initially investigated the stability, activity and selectivity of M-N4-C and M-N3X-C SACs (M represents 27 transition metal atoms, X = B, C, O, P, S) for CO2 → CO. Then, we combined the CO2RR data with machine learning (ML) to build a extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) model to predict the adsorption energy of CO (E ads(*CO)) of M-N4-C, M-N3X-C and M-N2X2-C SACs with encouraging 0.90 r 2 of test set. According to combination of DFT with ML, PtN3B (U L = -0.33 V), RhN4 (U L = -0.32 V), TiN2P2-ortho (U L = -0.47 V), FeN2O2-para (U L = -0.50 V), CoN4 (U L = -0.27 V), NiN3B (U L = -0.62 V) and CuN3B (U L = -0.29 V) have been identified as high-efficiency CO2RR catalysts. Furthermore, we proposed novel coordination environments for Fe-, Co-, Ni- and Cu-based SACs, widely investigated in the experimental field, toward enhanced CO2RR performance. As a result, this work provides an efficient ML model extracting the intrinsic properties of catalytic materials to design M-NX-C SACs for CO2RR. 2 Computational details 2.1 Structure model setup As shown in Fig. 1a ,b and Fig. S1, for all calculations, the models of SACs which contain 71 atoms were built by depositing M-N4-C, M-N3X-C or M-N2X2-C (X = B, C, O, P, S) moiety into 6 × 6 × 1 graphene supercell, the vacuum space was set to 20Å along the z-direction to avoid interactions between periodic structures. 2.2 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation methods All the spin-polarized calculations were performed with the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP-5.4.4) [46] by density functional theory (DFT). The projector augmented wave (PAW) [47] pseudopotentials were used to describe the electron-ion interactions. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) within generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functional was utilized to describe the exchange correlation interaction [48], and the van der Waals correction was described by the DFT-D3 method of Grimme [49]. A kinetic energy cutoff of 520 eV was used for the plane wave basis, and the convergence criteria for energy and force were set to 10−4 eV and 0.02 eV/Å. The Brillouin zone was sampled by a 2 × 2 × 1 Gamma-center Monkhorst-Pack for geometric optimization and 3 × 3 × 1 Gamma-center Monkhorst-Pack for static self-consistent field (SCF) calculation, Bader charge calculation, and 7 × 7 × 1 Gamma-center Monkhorst-Pack for the density of states (DOS) calculation [50]. Specially, the crystal orbital Hamilton populations (COHP) is performed by VASP and Lobster [51,52]. The aqueous environment of the reaction was treated with a implicit solvent model in VASPsol code,[53,54] with the dielectric constant set to 78.4. 2.3 Reaction free energy calculation The Gibbs free energy correction (G corr) was used to convert DFT energies into the Gibbs free energy with the following equation: (1) G corr = E ZPE + ∫ C p d T − T S ( + E gas ) where E ZPE, ∫C pdT, and -TS are zero-point energies, enthalpic and entropic contributions, respectively. They were calculated by a module in the software named Vaspkit [55]. E gas is a correction of the gas phase with the functional of GGA-PBE to improve alignment with experimental data [56]. The corresponding correction values are summarized in Table S1. The limiting potential (U L) of a reaction is defined as (2) U L = − Δ G max / e where ΔG max is the largest change in the free energy during CO2RR process. The E ads(*X) represents the adsorption energy of X (X = COOH, CO), which is given by (3) E ads ( * X ) = E ( * X ) − E ( * ) − E ( X ) where E(*X), E(*) and E(X) represent the DFT energy of *X, * and X, respectively. 2.4 Stability and selectivity evaluation The thermodynamic and electrochemical stabilities of M-N4/NX-C SACs were evaluated by the difference (E f’) between adsorption energy (E ads) and cohesive energy (E coh) and dissolution potential (U diss), respectively. The related equations are as follows: (4) E ads = E M − N 4 / NX − C − E N 4 / NX − C − E Single − M (5) E coh = ( E bulk − n × E Single − M ) / n (6) E f ′ = E ads − E coh (7) U diss = U diss ( M , bulk ) 0 − E f ′ e N e where E M-N4/NX-C, E N4/NX-C, E Single-M and E bulk represent the total energies of SACs (M-N4/NX-C), SACs without M atoms (N4/NX-C), the energy of the single M atom and the total energy of metal atoms in the most stable bulk structure, respectively; U diss ( M , bulk ) 0 and N e are the standard dissolution potential of bulk metal and the number of electrons involved in dissolution, respectively. Based on the definition, a SAC with E f’ < 0 eV and U diss > 0 V indicates that the formation of single-atomic moieties is thermodynamically and electrochemical favorable. These stability screening criteria have been used in several investigations [57–60]. The CO2RR pathway selectivity of SACs was described by the difference between the free energy of the *COOH and the free energy of the *OCHO (G sele), which are given by (8) G sele = G ( * COOH ) − G ( * OCHO ) the SACs with negative G sele are prone to generate CO during CO2RR. This strategy has been utilized in previous works [9,10,33,61,62]. The CO2RR vs HER selectivity was defined using the difference (U sele) between U L of CO2RR and U L of HER with the equation as follow (9) U sele = U L ( C O 2 RR ) − U L ( HER ) 2.5 Machine learning (ML) All ML predictions are performed using the open-source Scikit-learn library in the Python3 environment [63]. The parameter values of the extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) regression algorithms [64] used in this work are given in Table S2. Sixteen unique features which describe the property of the M-N4/NX-C SACs were selected as input to train the ML model. All training and test data was obtained from our DFT calculations. The data input was randomly divided into a training set and a test set in a 4 : 1 ratio, which is automatically executed by the code. Considering the quantity of data and the potential errors based on the segmentation process, a fivefold cross-validation approach was implemented to ensure the generalization of the model, this approach created five distinct training and test sets for ML model training and evaluation over five iterations. The optimal algorithm for E ads(*CO) prediction was determined by comparing the average values of coefficient of determination value (r 2) across five iterations; then, the best prediction of the test set was recorded. The mean absolute error (MAE), root mean-square error (RMSE), and r 2 were specified to measure the prediction errors and described as follow (10) MAE = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n | y i − y ^ i | (11) RMSE = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n ( y i − y ^ i ) 2 (12) r 2 = 1 − ∑ i = 1 n ( y ^ i − y i ) 2 ∑ i = 1 n ( y ¯ i − y i ) 2 In the above equations, y i , y ^ i and y ¯ i mean the ith value predicted by ML, the DFT calculation result, and the average value of the DFT calculation results, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stability of the M-N4-C/M-N3X-C SACs Fig. 1a,b show the structural configurations of M-N4-C and M-N3X-C (X = B, C, O, P and S) SACs, where 27 transition metal elements of 3d, 4d and 5d were considered as M while Tc was not considered because of its radioactivity (Fig. 1c). Based on the stability screening criteria (E f’ < 0 eV and U diss > 0 V), the M-NX-C SACs with various coordination environments fell in the second quadrant were considered stable and selected for further investigation, as shown in Fig. 1d-f. This includes 14 kinds of M-N4-C SACs, 17 kinds of M-N3C-C SACs, 9 kinds of M-N3S-C SACs, 9 kinds of M-N3P-C SACs, 9 kinds of M-N3O-C SACs, 10 kinds of M-N3B-C SACs. Note that the unstable M-N4-C (M = Ag, Os and Au) will meet the conditions when replacing one N with C. On the contrary, there are more unstable SACs in M-N3P-C, M-N3S-C, M-N3B-C and M-N3O-C than that in M-N4-C. The values of E f’ and U diss for evaluating the stabilities of SACs were calculated and summarized in Table S3. In order to consider the regularity which will be discussed later, a portion of unstable SACs (M = Mn, Mo, Ru, W, Re and Os) were also investigated. It is noteworthy that the experimentally synthesized M-N4-C and M-N3X-C SACs met the stability criteria [20,21,40,42,43], indicating that the criteria is reasonable. 3.2 Selectivity of the CO2RR reaction pathways There are two possible pathways for two proton-electron (H+ + e−) transfer steps of CO2RR. As shown in Fig. 2a , the first proton may approach O atom or C atom, forming *COOH (carboxyl species) or *OCHO (formate species), respectively; after the second hydrogenation step, the products of the two reaction pathways are CO and HCOOH (formic acid) [9,65]. Obviously, to generate *COOH in the first step is the key to obtain CO, which represents that the free energy of the *COOH (G(*COOH)) should be lower than that of the *OCHO (G(*OCHO)). Given the large number of coordination environments of M-NX-C SACs, it's too time-consuming to calculate the difference of those two the free energies (G sele) for all of those systems aiming to evaluate their reaction pathway selectivity. Therefore, we firstly performed test calculations of G sele for several metal centers coordinated with M-N4-C and M-N3X-C (X = B, C, O, P and S) aiming to filter some unexpected SACs for CO2 → CO. Fig. S2 shows that the sign of G sele is almost independent on local geometry of a certain metal atom and thus the estimations of reaction selectivity according to M-N4-C can be transported to M-N3X-C case [5,33]. The G sele values of 27 metal atoms in M-N4-C were calculated, considering the small variation of G sele around zero and calculation error, we selected G sele = 0.60 eV as the up-limit to avoid missing some potential candidates (see Fig. 2b). It can be seen that 15 metal atoms (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, W, Re, Os, Ir, Pt) pass the criteria of G sele < 0.60 eV, which fall completely within the VB to IB families [10]. Accordingly, we believed that those 15 metal atoms in M-N3X-C configurations may catalyze CO2RR to CO via *COOH. And the corresponding G sele values for M-N3X-C are listed in Table S4. Furthermore, we calculated the limiting potential as well as the free energies of reaction intermediates of CO2 → CO over M-N4-C and M-N3X-C SACs (132 systems, see Table S8), with several high-efficiency CO2RR catalysts listed in Table S5. We can see that CoN4 and FeN3S have been filtered out based on high throughput calculation, their excellent performance for CO2RR have been reported in the previous studies [6,23,34]. 3.3 Selectivity for CO2RR vs HER The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO (CO2 + 2H+ + 2e− = CO + H2O) is a reaction process with two proton-electron transfer steps, the HER, as a competitive side reaction, should be considered in this process. In order to determine the dominate reaction on the SACs, with the depiction of the previous investigations [18,22,25,66–68], the U L(CO2RR) - U L(HER) (U sele) is used and present in Fig. 3 . The more positive the U sele is, the higher the CO2RR selectivity of SACs. Note that the values of U sele for the two experimentally investigated high-efficiency CO2RR catalysts we have mentioned before are -0.21 V (CoN4) and -0.50 V (FeN3S), which is lower than a number of SACs we calculated. Aiming to screen out SACs with better performance, we defined U sele > 0 V as the screening criterion, with which we obtained 5 SACs of RhN4, MnN3P, WN3S, CuN3B and PtN3B possessing high selectivity. 3.4 SACs with outstanding overall performance With the aforementioned screening strategies, there are two SACs (PtN3B, RhN4) being singled out with competitive U L values, high CO product selectivity and superior performance in suppressing HER. The free energy diagrams of CO2RR and HER are plotted in Fig. 4a -b, which shows excellent CO2RR performance of PtN3B (U L = -0.33 V) and RhN4 (U L = -0.32 V) than HER catalytic activity, with the adsorption configurations of reaction intermediates (*COOH, *CO and *H) depicted in Fig. 4c-d. We can see that the potential determined step (PDS) of CO2RR over PtN3B involves the formation of *COOH. Bader charge analysis shows that upon the deposition of COOH, the PtN3B moiety lost 0.08 |e| to CO and 0.37 |e| to lattice carbons, respectively. For RhN4, the CO2RR process is limited by the desorption of CO and the corresponding charge transfer is 0.13 |e| from RhN4 moiety to adsorbed CO. The values of transferred charge are listed in Table S6. The charge transfer for both RhN4 and PtN3B are relatively small of nearly 0.10 |e|, which are smaller than several prior studies [6,24,57,69]. The tiny electron transfer and relatively small adsorption energy lead to the weak interactions between adsorbates and substrates, resulting in the low free energy barrier needed to overcome. The projected density of states (PDOS) of the two SACs are plotted in Fig. 5 , it shows that the electronic states near the Fermi energy are mainly contributed by the d xz and d yz orbitals of both metal centers, and the small band gap of PtN3B (0.16 eV) and metallic RhN4 suggests excellent conductivity of the catalysts. The lower d-band center of PtN3B (-2.13 eV) than RhN4 (-0.96 eV) would exhibit a weaker binding strength with intermediates [65]. Therefore, PtN3B binds more weakly than RhN4 to COOH and CO as shown in Fig. 4a. Nevertheless, the adsorption free energies of CO for two SACs are similar, which may be attributed to the introduction of B atom. The adsorption site of CO adsorbate on PtN3B is not merely on Pt site, but more like the bridge site between Pt and B, leading to the strengthened interaction between CO and PtN3B. This is consistent with the previous works reporting that B dopant in the carbon lattice behaves like M atom [70–72]. The Bader charge analysis also indicated that the B atom transfers more electrons (0.08 |e|) than N atom (0.01 |e|) after adsorbing CO. The impact of introducing B atoms on SAC is different from that of introducing other heteroatoms, which deserves more investigations. Besides, we also considered the solvent effect on the CO2RR performance of RhN4 and PtN3B by employing implicit solvent model. The results in Table S13 demonstrated that RhN4 (U L = -0.37 eV) and PtN3B (U L = -0.32 eV) still have excellent CO2RR performance considering solvent effect. 3.5 Machine learning (ML) There are a large number of configurations of heteroaotm-doped M-N4-C-catalysts, apart from M-N3X-C, several M-N2X2-C configurations have also been proposed and synthesized [39,41,73–75]. However, for the M-N2X2-C configuration, the presence of para and ortho positions and the complex screening steps significantly increases the computational workload. To address this issue, machine learning (ML) combined with DFT is utilized to predict the energy barrier of CO2RR. The previous works report that there is a linear scaling relationship between adsorbed key intermediates in CO2RR [62], which means that CO2RR performance of SACs can be roughly predicted by E ads(*CO) or E ads(*COOH). Therefore, we explored the relationship between U L and E ads(*COOH)/E ads(*CO) (Fig. 6 ). We can see that in areas with U L > -1.00 V, the span of E ads(*CO) is 1.71 eV, which is smaller than 2.02 eV for E ads(*COOH). Although the correlation is not strong, those SACs with promising catalytic performance can still be screened through moderate E ads(*CO) intervals. Hence, the E ads(*CO) can serve as a better indicator than E ads(*COOH) for preliminary screening of catalysts with fantastic CO2RR performance. Moreover, a previous work has built ML model to predict the E ads(*CO) of M-NX-C with fantastic r 2 = 0.90 [45], giving us confidence to establish a specific ML model to probe the CO2RR performance of M-NX-C. We next fed our DFT data into ML model to predict the E ads(*CO) of M-NX-C. There are 16 features selected to describe the structural properties of the SACs, 8 of the features (θ d, E M, IE, etc.) were selected based on the previous study [60]. Besides, two new features (N-N and N-X) and a one-hot feature (HA) were introduced to describe the local feature of M-N4/NX-C including M-N4-C, M-N3X-C and M-N2X2-C. The schematic diagrams of the different configurations of M-N4/NX-C were plotted in Fig. S1 and the descriptions of 16 features were placed in Table S7. By utilizing XGBoost model [45] with the detailed parameters depicted in section 2.5, the E ads(*CO) of M-N3X-C was successfully predicted with r 2 = 0.92 of test set. However, this model, named as old model, provides same predicted E ads(*CO) values for the para and ortho configurations of M-N2X2-C. Using the feature importance analysis, as shown in Fig. 7a , we found that the feature importance percentages of N-N and N-X are extremely small, representing that these two features contribute slightly to predict E ads(*CO). In this regard, additional DFT calculations of E ads(*CO) for 13 types of metal atom over all M-N2X2-C configurations (130 systems, see Table S8) were carried out and the data was added to build a new model, with all the data placed in Table S8. This new model can tell the difference of the para and ortho configurations of M-N2X2-C and the r 2 remains 0.90 (see Fig. 8a ), proving that this model has the capability of tackling various M-N4/NX-C geometries and strong generalization performance. The feature importance analysis of the new model was plotted in Fig. 7b. We can see the importance of the N-N feature has enhanced significantly. Besides, the rapid rising in importance for B indicated the specificity of B atom doping, which implies the specificity of B dopant demonstrated by previous works [70–72]. In conclusion, the new model is more realistic in estimating the importance of various features to predict E ads(*CO), and the d-electron number of central metals and the sum of valence electron number of surrounding atoms are the most important feature for activity prediction. Aiming to discuss how the target variable changes with feature values, we conducted SHapley Additive exPlanations analysis for new model. As Fig. S8 displayed, the value of E ads(*CO) is generally positively correlated with d-electron number, first ionization energy, and the sum of valence electron number of surrounding atoms, and negatively correlated with Pauling electronegativity. The result provides guidance for regulating a moderate E ads(*CO) value to achieve excellent CO2RR performance. In order to explore the generalization performance of this model, twenty SACs were selected to calculate E ads(*CO) for validating the prediction. Considering the range of predicted E ads(*CO) (-3.00 ∼ 0 eV), we defined 0.50 eV as the step size for picking up SACs with the horizon dashed lines indicated in Fig. 8b. In the region around -1.00 eV which is near the summit of volcano curve, we selected more SACs. The selected SACs and the corresponding values of E ads(*CO) are listed in Table S9. As Fig. 8b shows, the high r 2 of 0.86 and the low MAE (0.21 eV) and RMSE (0.26 eV) demonstrated that the model possesses faithful predictive ability. Therefore, we believed those SACs with E ads(*CO) ranging from -1.10 to -0.90 eV possess superior CO2RR performance. To approve this viewpoint, Zn- and Ti-based SACs (TiN3C, TiN2P2-ortho and ZnN2B2-para) were selected for further DFT calculations. The free energy diagrams of these three SACs were plotted in Fig. S3, with excellent U L of -0.47 V for TiN2P2-ortho. All the screened high-efficiency catalysts via ML-assisted DFT calculations were listed in Table S10. It's noteworthy that various of M-N4/NX-C has been successfully synthesized [18,34,73–76], which provided experimental guidance for synthetizing those screened SACs in this work. From above discussions, this ML model helps us rationally design quite a few promising heteroatom-doped M-N4-C SACs with terrific CO2RR performance, which deserves further investigation. 3.6 Experimental guidance Fe-, Co-, Ni- and Cu-based M-N4/NX-C SACs have been widely investigated with mature synthesis, toward wide range of applications including electrocatalytic CO2RR. In this work, we comprehensively investigated these four M-based SACs with M-N4-C, M-N3X-C and M-N2X2-C configurations in order to seek appropriate regulation of the coordination environment of M-N4-C for enhanced CO2RR performance. Firstly, in order to demonstrate the rationality of our calculation results, we took a few extensively studied SACs from the literature as examples and compared our data with previous works [77–88], as listed in Table S11. Our calculations are in good agreement with the previously reported results regarding of both PDS and U L values for different SACs, corroborating the validity and reliability of our calculations. Then, we provided the data for plotting the free energy diagrams and U L of CO2RR catalyzed by Fe-, Co-, Ni-, and Cu-based SACs with various coordination environments of M-NX-C in Fig. S4 and Table S12. To dig into the deep understanding of structure-property relationship, we selected six systems for each M-based SACs, covering three types of coordination environments (M-N4-C, M-N3X-C and M-N2X2-C) with less negative U L and the energy profiles are present in Fig. 9 . As Fig. 9a shows, over the Fe-based SACs, the PDS of CO2RR is the CO desorption independent on the local environment of metal center. This phenomenon also holds for Ni-based SACs with the reaction kinetics limited by the hydrogenation of CO2 (see Fig. 9c). On the contrary, the PDS for Co- and Cu-based SACs (Fig. 9b,d) alters with the coordination environments. The PDS of CO2RR is the formation of CO gas for CoN4 and CoN3P, while the other four Co-based SACs switch to the first step of hydrogenation. For Cu, each step in the two-electron transfer reactions of CO2RR has the potential to become PDS in these six SACs. Aiming to illustrate this phenomenon, the projected density of states of Co- and Cu-based SACs were calculated (Fig. S5). We can see that there is the largest overlap area between the 3d orbital of metal atom and the 2p orbital of CO for CoN3P in Co-based SACs, which shows the strongest interaction between adsorbed CO and substrates, corresponding to the highest energy barrier for the desorption of CO. Similarly, CuN2O2-para, with the largest overlap area, is supposed to possess the highest energy barrier. However, as Fig. 9d shows, the CuN2B2-para exhibit the strongest trapping capability for CO. This conflict can be attributed to the adsorption of CO over B site rather than Cu site in CuN2B2-para, which lead to the decrease of the overlap area. It's crucial to search for appropriate descriptors describing well the CO2RR performance of SACs. Therefore, we took Fe-based SACs as example and explored the correlation between U L and electronic properties, such as d band center, d-band center gap of spin states, charge transfer, Fe-C bond length, integrated crystal orbital Hamilton populations (ICOHP) and magnetic moment changes. Among them, the strongest correlations is found between d-band center gap of spin states of Fe-N4/NX-C and U L. More information are available in Figs. S6-7. Our DFT calculations demonstrated that adjusting the coordination environment has a significant impact on the CO2RR performance of SACs. As displayed in Fig. 9, SACs with the best performance appeared to be FeN2O2-para (U L = -0.50 V), CoN4 (U L = -0.27 V), NiN3B (U L = -0.62 V) and CuN3B (U L = -0.29 V), respectively. For these catalysts, the solvent effect on the CO2RR activity was also considered, the results also demonstrate that FeN2O2-para, CoN4, NiN3B and CuN3B possess excellent catalytic abilities, and the U L are -0.62, -0.32, -0.65 and -0.60 eV (Table S13), respectively. As outstanding SACs in each M-based 16 configurations (Fig. S4), FeN3S, NiN3B, CoN4 and FeN2O2-para have been identified as high-efficiency CO2RR catalysts in previous computational studies [6,23,34,76,89]. Among them, FeN3S, CoN4 and FeN2O2-para have been successfully synthesized so far [6,23,34,89], demonstrating that the theoretical calculations can provide the experimental guidance. It is worth mentioning that FeN2O2-para have just been reported very recently[89]. Therefore, those screened SACs shown in Fig. 9, in particular, NiN3B and CuN3B, deserve experimental research in the future. 4 Conclusion In this work, we performed ML-assisted DFT-based high-throughput calculations to rationally design SACs for CO2RR by introducing heteroatom into the first shell of M-N4-C. Initially, stability and selectivity criteria were utilized to seek high-efficiency M-N4-C and M-N3X-C SACs, and PtN3B (U L = -0.33 V) and RhN4 (U L = -0.32 V) were found with high selectivity of CO and CO2RR dominated performance. When screening the SACs, we noticed that the difference between G(*COOH) and G(*OCHO) mainly depends on the central metal atom, which provides an effective way to anticipate the pathway of two-electron transfer reactions for CO2RR. Besides, our calculations show that E ads(*CO) can serve as a preliminary descriptor to predict the U L of CO2RR. Thus, a XGBoost ML model was built to predict the E ads(*CO) of M-N3X-C and M-N2X2-C without additional DFT calculations. The DFT calculations validated the outstanding accuracy of the model, for example, TiN3C (U L = -0.68 V), TiN2P2-ortho (U L = -0.47 V) and ZnN2B2-para (U L = -0.85 V) were confirmed to possess superior CO2RR performance. Furthermore, we designed appropriate coordination environments for four widely investigated M-based (M= Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) SACs with the most competitive U L of -0.27 V, a part of them have been successfully synthesized in previous experiments. This investigation highlights that the coordination regulation is an effective way to improve the CO2RR performance of M-N4-C. We envision that our ML model has the potential to predict the catalytic performance of other M-NX-C configurations and guide future experimental works. coredata.dc:description: The local coordination environment regulation of M-N4-C type single-atom catalysts (SACs) by introducing heteroatom (X = B, C, O, P, S) have attracted significant attention for their controllable properties and fantastic catalytic activity in the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). However, the numerous possible configurations of M-NX-C result in excessive computational costs. Herein, we tackled that issue via machine learning-assisted density functional theory (DFT) calculations outperforming the conventional time-consuming high-throughput screening. Initially, DFT calculations demonstrate that the adsorption energy of CO can serve as a high-efficiency descriptor to predict the CO2RR performance of M-NX-C SACs. Then, using this descriptor we screened quite a few superior SACs toward CO2RR using machine learning model of extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) which can predict the catalytic performance of SACs with various parameters regarding local structures of metal centers. Those screened SACs of PtN3B, RhN4, TiN2P2-ortho, FeN2O2-para (experimentally proven recently), CoN4 (experimentally proven), NiN3B and CuN3B possess quite competitive limiting potentials, which have also been further validated by DFT calculations, exhibiting a faithful predictive ability of the XGBoost model. Besides, effective regulation strategies of local environments for promising CO2RR performance were proposed for the most widely investigated M-N4-C (M = Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) SACs. This work is significant for understanding the mechanism of the nearest neighbor regulation of M-N4-C SACs for CO2RR and guiding the future experimental synthesis of them.
